src:
Banyak Masalah di RI, Bos Bukalapak: Justru Potensi Startup Besar
02 Nov 2019, 23:27 by Pribadi Wicaksono (Kontributor), Rr. Ariyani Yakti Widyastuti
TEMPO.CO, Jakarta - Salah satu pendiri e-commerce Bukalapak, Muhammad Fajrin Rasyid menyebutkan bisnis startup sebenarnya potensial untuk Indonesia yang merupakan negara berkembang. Setumpuk masalah yang ditemui di Tanah Air seperti pengangguran, kemiskinan, indeks daya saing dan lainnya malah dinilai sebagai potensi pengembangan startup.
"Kalau dibilang Indonesia masih banyak masalah, mungkin iya. Namun jangan hanya melihat dari sisi itu saja. Justru karena dibilang banyak masalah itu potensi mengembangkan startup di Indonesia besar," ujar Fajrin, saat berbicara di acara Jogja Startup Day 2019 di Universitas Amikom Yogyakarta, Sabtu, 2 November 2019.
Sebagai contoh, Fajrin bercerita, sepanjang tahun ini saja, ia sudah tiga kali diundang untuk bicara di Korea Selatan. Sebab di negeri ginseng nan maju industrinya itu ternyata ekosistem startupnya tak semaju dan se-menggeliat seperti di Indonesia.
Lebih jauh Fajrin yang juga Co-Founder dan President Bukalapak, menuturkan para pemula yang berniat terjun bisnis startup harus punya mental tahan banting. Pasalnya, selama ini sejumlah startup yang terekspos di media massa kebanyakan yang skalanya sudah besar, sukses dan mapan.
Padahal startup yang gagal atau bangkrut jumlahnya lebih banyak. "Sebanyak 90 persen atau ada yang bilang pula 95 persen startup yang dibuat itu gagal (diterima pasar)," ujar Fajrin
12 Selanjutnya
text:
Many Problems in RI, Bukalapak Boss: Precisely Big Startup Potential
02 Nov 2019, 23:27 by Pribadi Wicaksono (Contributor), Rr. Ariyani Yakti Widyastuti
TEMPO.CO, Jakarta - One of Bukalapak's e-commerce founders, Muhammad Fajrin Rasyid, said that startup business is actually a potential for Indonesia, which is a developing country. A pile of problems encountered in the country such as unemployment, poverty, competitiveness index and others are even considered as a potential for startup development.
"If you say Indonesia is still a lot of problems, maybe yes. But don't just look at it from that side. Precisely because there are many problems that say the potential for developing startups in Indonesia is big," Fajrin said, while speaking at the Jogja Startup Day 2019 at Amikom University in Yogyakarta, Saturday, November 2, 2019.
For example, Fajrin told, during this year alone, he had been invited to speak three times in South Korea. Because in the developed country of ginseng, the industry turns out that the startup ecosystem is not as advanced and stretching as in Indonesia.
Furthermore, Fajrin, who is also the Co-Founder and President of Bukalapak, said that beginners who intend to enter the startup business must have a resilient mentality. Because, so far a number of startups exposed to the mass media are mostly large-scale, successful and established.
Though startups that fail or go bankrupt are more numerous. "As many as 90 percent or some say also 95 percent of startups that were made failed (accepted by the market)," said Fajrin
